posts._title: Robert Day – Tarzan and the Great River (1967)
posts.title: Tarzan and the Great River
posts.excerpt: Plot:Tarzan is summoned to Brazil by an old friend to stop an evil tribal cult from destroying native villages and enslaving the survivors. The Lord of the Jungle is accompanied on his quest by a pretty blonde doctor, a boy and a grizzled sea captain. Written by Marty M.

posts._title: Daniel Mann – The Teahouse of the August Moon (1956)
posts.title: The Teahouse of the August Moon
posts.excerpt: Teahouse retains the basic appeal that made it a unique war novel and a legit hit. There is some added slapstick for those who prefer their comedy broader. Adding to its prospects are some top comedy characterizations, notably from Glenn Ford, plus the offbeat casting of Marlon Brando in a comedy role.In transferring his play …

posts.title: Juan Moreira
posts.excerpt: AllMovie wrote:In this amazing and complex Argentine historical drama, much of the true story of the 19th-century assassin Juan Moreira comes to the screen. At the time of its release, this Argentine film was the most popular locally made film ever to be shown there. Juan Moreira was a popular folk hero on a par …

posts.title: Hotel Chevalier
posts.excerpt: A short epilogue of one heartbreaking history of love and the prologue of the travel told in “The Darjeeling Limited”, starring Natalie Portman and Jason Schwartzman.

posts._title: Chris Marker – L’ambassade AKA The Embassy (1973)
posts.title: L’ambassade
posts.excerpt: An unexpected response to Pinochet’s 1973 coup d’etat in Chile. A Super-8 film apparently found in an embassy -as it’s written in the original title-, where political activists had taken refuge after a military coup d’état. But the events -and their setting- are not what they first appear to be.

posts._title: Monika Treut – Die Jungfrauenmaschine AKA Virgin Machine (1988)
posts.title: Die Jungfrauenmaschine
posts.excerpt: synopsisDorothee, a would-be writer and journalist, leaves Germany for the Oz of San Francisco, searching for her long-lost mother and a cure for the malady of love. Installed in the Tenderloin, she peeps in on neighbors’ bizarre sex rituals as well as does sightseeing of the more traditional kind. But encounters with male impersonator Ramona, …

posts._title: Zhangke Jia – Xiaoshan huijia AKA Xiao Shan Going Home (1995)
posts.title: Xiaoshan huijia
posts.excerpt: Xiao Shan, a temporary worker at the Hongyuan Restaurant, has just been fired by his boss Zhao Guoqing. Deciding to leave Beijing and returns to his home in Anyang, he goes to see a series of people from his hometown who have also been living in Beijing -construction workers, train ticket scalpers, university students, attendant, …

posts._title: Yimou Zhang – Hong gao liang AKA Red Sorghum [91min edit] (1988)
posts.title: Hong gao liang
posts.excerpt: Quote: Celebrated Mainland filmmaker Zhang Yimou brings his inimitable touch to Red Sorghum, a sumptuous drama set during 1930s China, just prior to the Japanese occupation. posts._title: Nagisa Ôshima – Watashi-wa beretto AKA It’s Me Here, Bellett (1964)
posts.title: Watashi-wa beretto
posts.excerpt: Quote:Watashi-wa beretto is a promotional film for the automobile manufacturer Isuzu Jidosha directed by Nagisa Ôshima. Yasujirô Ozu assisted as executive creative consultant.

posts.title: Buried in Light
posts.excerpt: “A meditation on history, memory, and change in Central and Eastern Europe, Buried in Light is a non-narrative journey, a cinematic collage. Cohen’s “search for images” began at a time of extraordinary flux, as the Berlin Wall was dismantled—opening borders yet ushering in a nascent wave of consumer capitalism. What he saw struck him as …
